subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file
msgSnippet: More to the point: testing with the file system is a bitch at the best of times. A common idea is to kill a folder on the file system after every test, in
messageBody:
More to the point: testing with the file system is a bitch at the best
of times. A common idea is to kill a folder on the file system after
every test, in order to start with a "clean slate". Unfortunately, the
tests are too fast for the file system, so the file system isn't clean
before the next test starts. Result: chaos.

The moral of the story is this: don't test against the file system any
more than you absolutely have to.

On 2002-09-06 at 11:07 Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>> Please guide me on how to write test cases where the input to the
test
>> cases will come as element values from a xml file.
>
>Instead of reading from a file, pass an InputSource to your method
(for
>example):
>
> String input = "<property name=\"name1\" value=\"value1\" />";
> myClass.read(new InputSource(new StringReader(input)));
>
>Remember: you don't want to test if the JVM can read the file, but
what
>your
>class does with the file.
>
>-Vladimir
